print: interface ArrayDataSourceProps<TItem, TId, TFilter> extends ArrayListViewProps<TItem, TId, TFilter> {

props.name: sortSearchByRelevance
comment: Enables sorting of search results by relevance.
- The highest priority has records, which have a full match with a search keyword.
- The lower one has records, which have a search keyword at the 0 position, but not the full match.
- Then, records, which contain a search keyword as a separate word, but not at the beginning.
- And the lowest one - any other match of the search keyword.
Example:
- `search`: 'some'
- `record string`: 'some word', `rank` = 4
- `record string`: 'someone', `rank` = 3
- `record string`: 'I know some guy', `rank` = 2
- `record string`: 'awesome', `rank` = 1
@default true

props.name: getId
comment: Should return unique ID of the TItem
If omitted, we assume that every TItem has and unique id in its 'id' field.
@param item An item to get ID of

props.name: complexIds
comment: Set to true, if you use IDs which can't act as javascript Map key (objects or arrays).
In this case, IDs will be internally JSON.stringify-ed to be used as Maps keys.

props.name: getParentId
comment: Should return ID of the Item's parent. Usually it's i => i.parentId.
If specified, Data Source will build items hierarchy.
Also, it is used by LazyDataSource to pre-fetch missing parents of loaded items. This is required in following cases:
- when a child item is pre-selected, but not yet loaded at start. We need to load it's parent chain
to highlight parents with selected children
- in flattenSearch mode, we usually want to display a path to each item (e.g. Canada/Ontario/Paris),
We need to load parents with a separate call (if backend doesn't pre-fetch them)

props.name: rowOptions
comment: Specifies if rows are selectable, checkable, draggable, clickable, and more.
See DataRowOptions for more details.
If options depends on the item itself, use getRowOptions.
Specifying both rowOptions and getRowOptions might help to render better loading skeletons: we use only rowOptions in this case, as we haven't loaded an item yet.
Make sure all callbacks are properly memoized, as changing them will trigger re-renders or row, which would impact performance
@param item An item to get options for

props.name: getRowOptions
comment: For each row, specify if row is selectable, editable, checkable, draggable, clickable, have its own set of columns, and more.
To make rows editable, pass IEditable interface to each row. This works the same way as for other editable components.
See DataRowOptions for more details.
If both getRowOptions and rowOptions specified, we'll use getRowOptions for loaded rows, and rowOptions only for loading rows.
Make sure all callbacks are properly memoized, as changing them will trigger re-renders or row, which would impact performance
@param item An item to get options for

typeValue.raw: undefined | (item: TItem, index: number) => DataRowOptions<TItem, TId>

props.name: isFoldedByDefault
comment: Can be specified to unfold all or some items at start.
If not specified, all rows would be folded.

props.name: cascadeSelection
comment: Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
- false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
- true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
- 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.

props.name: selectAll
comment: Enables or disables "select all" checkbox. Default is true.

props.name: backgroundReload
comment: Enables background reloading of data on search/sort/filter/reload, which turns off the rows placeholders displaying while data loading.
During data reloading, previous data is displayed. To prevent any interaction with visible not actual rows, a blocker/spinner should be displayed.
In UUI components, such as `PickerInput`, `PickerList`, `PickerModal` and `DataTable`, blockers are added.
It is required to add blockers/spinners to the components, built on your own.
If reloading is started, `view.getListProps` returns `isReloading` flag, set to `true`.

getRowOptions?(item: TItem, index: number): DataRowOptions<TItem, TId>;
* Can be specified to unfold all or some items at start.
* If not specified, all rows would be folded.
* Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
* - false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
* - true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
* - 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
*   The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
*   parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
*   its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
*   unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.
* Enables or disables "select all" checkbox. Default is true.
* Enables background reloading of data on search/sort/filter/reload, which turns off the rows placeholders displaying while data loading.
* During data reloading, previous data is displayed. To prevent any interaction with visible not actual rows, a blocker/spinner should be displayed.
* In UUI components, such as `PickerInput`, `PickerList`, `PickerModal` and `DataTable`, blockers are added.
* It is required to add blockers/spinners to the components, built on your own.
* If reloading is started, `view.getListProps` returns `isReloading` flag, set to `true`.

props.name: getId
comment: Should return unique ID of the TItem
If omitted, we assume that every TItem has and unique id in its 'id' field.
@param item An item to get ID of

props.name: complexIds
comment: Set to true, if you use IDs which can't act as javascript Map key (objects or arrays).
In this case, IDs will be internally JSON.stringify-ed to be used as Maps keys.

props.name: getParentId
comment: Should return ID of the Item's parent. Usually it's i => i.parentId.
If specified, Data Source will build items hierarchy.
Also, it is used by LazyDataSource to pre-fetch missing parents of loaded items. This is required in following cases:
- when a child item is pre-selected, but not yet loaded at start. We need to load it's parent chain
to highlight parents with selected children
- in flattenSearch mode, we usually want to display a path to each item (e.g. Canada/Ontario/Paris),
We need to load parents with a separate call (if backend doesn't pre-fetch them)

props.name: rowOptions
comment: Specifies if rows are selectable, checkable, draggable, clickable, and more.
See DataRowOptions for more details.
If options depends on the item itself, use getRowOptions.
Specifying both rowOptions and getRowOptions might help to render better loading skeletons: we use only rowOptions in this case, as we haven't loaded an item yet.
Make sure all callbacks are properly memoized, as changing them will trigger re-renders or row, which would impact performance
@param item An item to get options for

props.name: getRowOptions
comment: For each row, specify if row is selectable, editable, checkable, draggable, clickable, have its own set of columns, and more.
To make rows editable, pass IEditable interface to each row. This works the same way as for other editable components.
See DataRowOptions for more details.
If both getRowOptions and rowOptions specified, we'll use getRowOptions for loaded rows, and rowOptions only for loading rows.
Make sure all callbacks are properly memoized, as changing them will trigger re-renders or row, which would impact performance
@param item An item to get options for

typeValue.raw: undefined | (item: TItem, index: number) => DataRowOptions<TItem, TId>

props.name: isFoldedByDefault
comment: Can be specified to unfold all or some items at start.
If not specified, all rows would be folded.

props.name: cascadeSelection
comment: Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
- false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
- true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
- 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.

props.name: selectAll
comment: Enables or disables "select all" checkbox. Default is true.

props.name: backgroundReload
comment: Enables background reloading of data on search/sort/filter/reload, which turns off the rows placeholders displaying while data loading.
During data reloading, previous data is displayed. To prevent any interaction with visible not actual rows, a blocker/spinner should be displayed.
In UUI components, such as `PickerInput`, `PickerList`, `PickerModal` and `DataTable`, blockers are added.
It is required to add blockers/spinners to the components, built on your own.
If reloading is started, `view.getListProps` returns `isReloading` flag, set to `true`.

print: /* The ClassValue type is a union type that represents the valid values that can be passed as arguments to the classnames function. It can be one of the following types:
- string: A string representing a class name.
- number: A number representing a class name. This is useful when using CSS modules.

- ClassDictionary: An object whose keys are class names and values are booleans. If the value is true, the corresponding class name will be included in the resulting string, otherwise it will be omitted.
- ClassArray: An array of values of type ClassValue. This allows you to pass multiple class names or class dictionaries as arguments to classnames.
- undefined: If undefined is passed as an argument, it will be ignored.
- null: If null is passed as an argument, it will be ignored.
- boolean: If a boolean value is passed as an argument, it will be ignored if it is false and included if it is true. */
type ClassValue = string | number | ClassDictionary | ClassArray | undefined | null | boolean;

comment: DataRowProps is a base shape of props, passed to items in various lists or trees.
Despite 'Row' in it's name, it doesn't directly connected to a table.
We use DataRowProps as a base for DataTableRowProps and DataPickerRowProps.
But it can also be used for any user-built list, tree, custom picker rows, or even a grid of cards.
Array of DataRowProps describes a part of hierarchical list, while still being a flat array (not a tree of some kind).
We use depth, indent, path, and other props to show row's place in the hierarchy.
This is very handy to handle rendering, especially in virtual scrolling scenarios.
DataSources primary job is to convert various data stores into arrays of DataRowProps.

print: /** DataRowProps is a base shape of props, passed to items in various lists or trees.
* Despite 'Row' in it's name, it doesn't directly connected to a table.
* We use DataRowProps as a base for DataTableRowProps and DataPickerRowProps.
* But it can also be used for any user-built list, tree, custom picker rows, or even a grid of cards.
* Array of DataRowProps describes a part of hierarchical list, while still being a flat array (not a tree of some kind).
* We use depth, indent, path, and other props to show row's place in the hierarchy.
* This is very handy to handle rendering, especially in virtual scrolling scenarios.
* DataSources primary job is to convert various data stores into arrays of DataRowProps.
type DataRowProps<TItem, TId> = FlexRowProps & DataRowOptions<TItem, TId> & {
/** ID of the TItem rows displays */
/** Key to be used as component's key when rendering. Usually, it's stringified ID */
/** Index of the row, from the top of the list. This doesn't account any hierarchy. */
/** The data item (TItem) row displays. Will be undefined if isLoading = true. */
/** Hierarchical path from the root node to the item (excluding the item itself) */
/** Depth of the row in tree, 0 for the top-level */
/** Indent of the item, to show hierarchy.
*  Unlike depth, it contains additional logic, to not add unnecessary indents:
*  if all children of node has no children, all nodes would get the same indent as parent.
/** True if row is in loading state. 'value' is empty in this case */
/** True if row be folded or unfolded (usually because it contains children) */
/** True if row is currently folded */
/** True if row is checked with checkbox */
/** True if row has checkbox and can be checkable */
/** True if some of row's children are checked.
* Used to show 'indefinite' checkbox state, to show user that something inside is checked */
/** True if row is selected (in single-select mode, or in case when interface use both single row selection and checkboxes) */
/** True if any of row's children is selected. */
/** True if row is focused. Focus can be changed via keyboard arrow keys, or by hovering mouse on top of the row */
/** True if row is the last child of his parent */
* We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

print: interface DndActorProps<TSrcData, TDstData> extends IDndActor<TSrcData, TDstData> {
/** True, if the element can be dragged. Doesn't mean that DnD is active. */
/** True, if the element is dragged out. True for placeholder left when it's element it dragged out. False for Drag Ghost. */
/** True, if the element is rendered as Drag Ghost. All other flags are false for drag ghost. */
/** True, if the element is being dragged over, even if drop is not accepted by the element (canAcceptDrop returned false) */
/** True, if the element is being dragged over, and drop on it is accepted - canAcceptDrop returned true */
/** True if any drag and drop operation is in progress, even if the element not being dragged */
/** Drag data associated with the element. Specified always, even if there is no DnD operation happening. */
/** Drop position. Chosen from accepted drop positions according to pointer coordinates */
* Event handlers. Component is expected to pass these events to the top element it renders.
* As onClick event on the element will be overwritten, use DndActorProps.onClick to receive click events on the element
* CSS class names to add to the element.
* Some of these markers are used by the DndActor internally, so they must be added even if no used by component itself to apply styles.
* Ref to the DOM element to perform DnD actions

props.name: isDraggable
comment: True, if the element can be dragged. Doesn't mean that DnD is active.

comment: True, if the element is dragged out. True for placeholder left when it's element it dragged out. False for Drag Ghost.

props.name: isDragGhost
comment: True, if the element is rendered as Drag Ghost. All other flags are false for drag ghost.

props.name: isDraggedOver
comment: True, if the element is being dragged over, even if drop is not accepted by the element (canAcceptDrop returned false)

props.name: isDropAccepted
comment: True, if the element is being dragged over, and drop on it is accepted - canAcceptDrop returned true

props.name: isDndInProgress
comment: True if any drag and drop operation is in progress, even if the element not being dragged

props.name: dragData
comment: Drag data associated with the element. Specified always, even if there is no DnD operation happening.

props.name: position
comment: Drop position. Chosen from accepted drop positions according to pointer coordinates

props.name: eventHandlers
comment: Event handlers. Component is expected to pass these events to the top element it renders.
As onClick event on the element will be overwritten, use DndActorProps.onClick to receive click events on the element

print: /** Current value of the form state */
* Render the form body, provided by form state
* Returns form metadata - information used to validate the form.
* @param state Metadata can depend on state, and will be re-computed on updates
* Occurs when 'save' function is called on Form.
* Should save form data (usually with API call to server).
* Server can also reject form, and provide validation errors in response.
* Called when form is unmounted, but user still have unsaved changes.
* Accepts a Promise<boolean> to be returned. If promise resolves to true - save procedure is performed.
* The common use-case is to show a modal with "Save Changes?" dialog
* Skins usually implement this as default behavior. To prevent it, you can pass null to this prop to override it.
* Used to restore unsaved user edits from the last session (usually to localstorage, via uuiUserSettings context)
* If unsaved changes are detected, this callback is called. If it is resolved - the form restores unsaved edits.
* The common use-case is to show a modal with "You have unsaved changes, restore them?" dialog
* Skins usually implement this as default behavior. To prevent it, you can pass null to this prop to override it.
* @param isSavedBeforeLeave true, if save is triggered via leaving the page, and "Save Changes?" dialog
* The key, under which form save unsaved state usually to localstorage, via uuiUserSettings context)
* save (default, recommended) - form is validated on save. If form is invalid - it will be revalidated on every change, until become valid
* change - form is validated on every user change. Only fields changes in current edit session are validated

print: * Lens - a helper to split parts of the form state, validation, and setState callbacks, and pass this to components
* Sets form value. The signature is the same for setState in React.useState - either new value, or callback to update the value.
* The change is threated as user input - sets isChanged and creates undo endpoint
* Replaces form value. The signature is the same for setState in React.useState - either new value, or callback to update the value.
* The change is not threated as user input - it replaces last changed state, and doesn't create undo checkpoint.
* Triggers save procedure - validation, calling props.onSave, and processing results
* Reverts all changes up to the initial or last saved state
* Try to leave form and ask to save unsaved changes
* Validation is usually done automatically, according to validationOn prop.
* Use this method only in corner cases.
/** True if there are changes to undo */
/** True if there are changes to redo */
/** True if there are changes to revers */
/** True if form is changed since the initial state, or the last save */
/** True if save is in progress */

The change is threated as user input - sets isChanged and creates undo endpoint

comment: Component can accept cx variable, which is more convenient shortcut for 'classname' property
It accepts string, arrays, object, recursively. All falsy values are thrown away. Examples:
- 'red' => 'red'
- ['red', 0, false, 'blue' ] => 'red blue'
- { 'red': true, 'blue': false, ['green', 'white']} => 'red green white'

print: interface LazyDataSourceProps<TItem, TId, TFilter> extends LazyListViewProps<TItem, TId, TFilter> {

props.name: api
comment: A function to retrieve the data, asynchronously.
This function usually performs a REST API call.
API is used to retrieve lists of items.
It is expected to:
- be able to handle paging (via from/count params)
- be able to retrieve specific items by the list of their ids
- be able to retrieve children by parents (when getChildCount is specified, and ctx.parentId is passed)

props.name: getChildCount
comment: Should return number of children of the item.
If it returns > 0, the item is assumed to have children and to be foldable.
Usually, this value should be returned from API.
If you can't get number of children via API, you can return a guess value (avg number of children for this type of entity).
Note, that this can lead to more API calls, and increased load times in the 'parallel' fetch mode.
@param item

props.name: filter
comment: A filter to pass to API.
Note, that the DataSourceState also has a filter fields. These two filters are merged before API calls.
Use this prop if you need to apply some filter in any case.
Prefer to use filter in the DataSourceState for end-user editable filters.

props.name: fetchStrategy
comment: Defines how to fetch children:
sequential (default) - fetch children for each parent one-by-one. Makes minimal over-querying, at cost of some speed.
parallel - fetch children for several parents simultaneously. Can make a lot of over-querying for deep trees.
Recommended for 2 level trees (grouping), as it makes no over-querying in this case, and is faster than sequential strategy.

props.name: flattenSearchResults
comment: Falls back to plain list from tree, if there's search.
Default is true.
If enabled, and search is active:
- API will be called with parentId and parent undefined
- getChildCount is ignored, all nodes are assumed to have no children
See more here: https://github.com/epam/UUI/issues/8

props.name: legacyLoadDataBehavior
comment: This options is added for the purpose of supporting legacy behavior of fetching data
on `getVisibleRows` and `getListProps`, not to break users' own implementation of dataSources.
@default true

props.name: getId
comment: Should return unique ID of the TItem
If omitted, we assume that every TItem has and unique id in its 'id' field.
@param item An item to get ID of

props.name: complexIds
comment: Set to true, if you use IDs which can't act as javascript Map key (objects or arrays).
In this case, IDs will be internally JSON.stringify-ed to be used as Maps keys.

props.name: getParentId
comment: Should return ID of the Item's parent. Usually it's i => i.parentId.
If specified, Data Source will build items hierarchy.
Also, it is used by LazyDataSource to pre-fetch missing parents of loaded items. This is required in following cases:
- when a child item is pre-selected, but not yet loaded at start. We need to load it's parent chain
to highlight parents with selected children
- in flattenSearch mode, we usually want to display a path to each item (e.g. Canada/Ontario/Paris),
We need to load parents with a separate call (if backend doesn't pre-fetch them)

props.name: rowOptions
comment: Specifies if rows are selectable, checkable, draggable, clickable, and more.
See DataRowOptions for more details.
If options depends on the item itself, use getRowOptions.
Specifying both rowOptions and getRowOptions might help to render better loading skeletons: we use only rowOptions in this case, as we haven't loaded an item yet.
Make sure all callbacks are properly memoized, as changing them will trigger re-renders or row, which would impact performance
@param item An item to get options for

props.name: getRowOptions
comment: For each row, specify if row is selectable, editable, checkable, draggable, clickable, have its own set of columns, and more.
To make rows editable, pass IEditable interface to each row. This works the same way as for other editable components.
See DataRowOptions for more details.
If both getRowOptions and rowOptions specified, we'll use getRowOptions for loaded rows, and rowOptions only for loading rows.
Make sure all callbacks are properly memoized, as changing them will trigger re-renders or row, which would impact performance
@param item An item to get options for

typeValue.raw: undefined | (item: TItem, index: number) => DataRowOptions<TItem, TId>

props.name: isFoldedByDefault
comment: Can be specified to unfold all or some items at start.
If not specified, all rows would be folded.

props.name: cascadeSelection
comment: Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
- false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
- true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
- 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.

props.name: selectAll
comment: Enables or disables "select all" checkbox. Default is true.

props.name: backgroundReload
comment: Enables background reloading of data on search/sort/filter/reload, which turns off the rows placeholders displaying while data loading.
During data reloading, previous data is displayed. To prevent any interaction with visible not actual rows, a blocker/spinner should be displayed.
In UUI components, such as `PickerInput`, `PickerList`, `PickerModal` and `DataTable`, blockers are added.
It is required to add blockers/spinners to the components, built on your own.
If reloading is started, `view.getListProps` returns `isReloading` flag, set to `true`.

print: interface LazyListViewProps<TItem, TId, TFilter> extends BaseListViewProps<TItem, TId, TFilter> {
* A function to retrieve the data, asynchronously.
* This function usually performs a REST API call.
* API is used to retrieve lists of items.
* - be able to handle paging (via from/count params)
* - be able to retrieve specific items by the list of their ids
* - be able to retrieve children by parents (when getChildCount is specified, and ctx.parentId is passed)
* Should return number of children of the item.
* If it returns > 0, the item is assumed to have children and to be foldable.
* Usually, this value should be returned from API.
* If you can't get number of children via API, you can return a guess value (avg number of children for this type of entity).
* Note, that this can lead to more API calls, and increased load times in the 'parallel' fetch mode.
* A filter to pass to API.
* Note, that the DataSourceState also has a filter fields. These two filters are merged before API calls.
* Use this prop if you need to apply some filter in any case.
* Prefer to use filter in the DataSourceState for end-user editable filters.
* sequential (default) - fetch children for each parent one-by-one. Makes minimal over-querying, at cost of some speed.
* parallel - fetch children for several parents simultaneously. Can make a lot of over-querying for deep trees.
*      Recommended for 2 level trees (grouping), as it makes no over-querying in this case, and is faster than sequential strategy.
* Falls back to plain list from tree, if there's search.
* If enabled, and search is active:
* - API will be called with parentId and parent undefined
* - getChildCount is ignored, all nodes are assumed to have no children
* This options is added for the purpose of supporting legacy behavior of fetching data
* on `getVisibleRows` and `getListProps`, not to break users' own implementation of dataSources.

comment: Defines which value is to set on clear. E.g. you can put an empty array instead of null for empty multi-select Pickers

props.name: sortBy
comment: Defines how items should be sorted. By default, items are shown in order they are provided to the DataSource

props.name: filter
comment: Additional filter to apply to the DataSource. Can be used to limit selection somehow, w/o re-building the DataSource. E.g. in the linked pickers scenario.

props.name: sorting
comment: Defines sorting to pass to the DataSource

props.name: cascadeSelection
comment: Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
- false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
- true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
- 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.

props.name: isFoldedByDefault
comment: You can return true for all, or some items to fold them.

props.name: getSearchFields
comment: Given an item, should return an array of string fields to search on. By default, the search is performed on item.name field.

@param state Form state to save

props.name: beforeLeave
comment: Called when form is unmounted, but user still have unsaved changes.
Accepts a Promise<boolean> to be returned. If promise resolves to true - save procedure is performed.
The common use-case is to show a modal with "Save Changes?" dialog
Skins usually implement this as default behavior. To prevent it, you can pass null to this prop to override it.

props.name: loadUnsavedChanges
comment: Used to restore unsaved user edits from the last session (usually to localstorage, via uuiUserSettings context)
If unsaved changes are detected, this callback is called. If it is resolved - the form restores unsaved edits.
The common use-case is to show a modal with "You have unsaved changes, restore them?" dialog
Skins usually implement this as default behavior. To prevent it, you can pass null to this prop to override it.

props.name: validationOn

save (default, recommended) - form is validated on save. If form is invalid - it will be revalidated on every change, until become valid
change - form is validated on every user change. Only fields changes in current edit session are validated

print: /** Holds state of a Virtual List - top visible item index, and estimated count of visible items */
* Virtual list ensures that row with this Index is within the visible area, if not Virtual List .
* Virtual list updates this value on scroll to null when appear in the visible area.
* If this value is updated manually, Virtual List would scroll to the specified items.
* It would attempt to put scroll so this item will be at the top of the list.
* Virtual List manually scroll to this Index when it appears not within the visible area.
* It would attempt to put scroll so this item will be in the middle of the list.

comment: Virtual list ensures that row with this Index is within the visible area, if not Virtual List .
Virtual list updates this value on scroll to null when appear in the visible area.
If this value is updated manually, Virtual List would scroll to the specified items.
It would attempt to put scroll so this item will be at the top of the list.

props.name: focusedIndex
comment: Virtual List manually scroll to this Index when it appears not within the visible area.
It would attempt to put scroll so this item will be in the middle of the list.

* Pass true to wrap DropdownContainer with FocusLock component to support keyboard navigation.
* If omitted, true value will be used.
* After DropdownContainer appeared the focus will be set on the first focusable element inside.
* Pass true to return focus into initial position on unmount.
* If omitted, true value will be used. It's used if focusLock=true.
* Pass true to lock focus within DropdownContainer.
* If omitted, true value will be used. It's used if focusLock=true.
* Pass any extra props to the FocusLock wrapper.
* Pass an array of ref pointing to the nodes, which focus lock should consider and a part of it. This is a way of focus scattering.
* Pass element name if you need to change internal FocusLock div element, to any other.
* Pass true to handle Escape key press and call props.onClose().
* If omitted, true value will be used. It's used if focusLock=true.
/** Called on keyDown event in DropdownContainer.
Can be used to provide your own handlers.

props.name: focusLock
comment: Pass true to wrap DropdownContainer with FocusLock component to support keyboard navigation.
If omitted, true value will be used.
After DropdownContainer appeared the focus will be set on the first focusable element inside.

props.name: returnFocus
comment: Pass true to return focus into initial position on unmount.
If omitted, true value will be used. It's used if focusLock=true.

props.name: persistentFocus
comment: Pass true to lock focus within DropdownContainer.
If omitted, true value will be used. It's used if focusLock=true.

props.name: lockProps
comment: Pass any extra props to the FocusLock wrapper.

props.name: shards
comment: Pass an array of ref pointing to the nodes, which focus lock should consider and a part of it. This is a way of focus scattering.

props.name: as
comment: Pass element name if you need to change internal FocusLock div element, to any other.

props.name: closeOnEsc
comment: Pass true to handle Escape key press and call props.onClose().
If omitted, true value will be used. It's used if focusLock=true.

props.name: onKeyDown
comment: Called on keyDown event in DropdownContainer.
Can be used to provide your own handlers.

/** dropdown (default) - show selection in dropdown; modal - opens modal window to select items */
/** Maximum number of tags to display in input, before collapsing to "N items selected" mode */
/** Prevents selected items tags to occupy multiple lines  */
/** Dropdown position relative to the input. See [Popper Docs](@link https://popper.js.org/) */
/** Replaces default 'toggler' - an input to which Picker attaches dropdown */
* 'input' - try to place search inside the toggler (default for single-select),
* 'body' - put search inside the dropdown (default for multi-select)
/** Disallow to clear Picker value (cross icon) */
* Minimum characters to type, before search will trigger. If input characters number is less then 'minCharsToSearch', it will disable opening dropdown body.
* By default search triggers after input value is changed.
* Note: defined minCharsToSearch isn't compatible with searchPosition=body.
/** Overrides default height of the dropdown body */
/** Sets focus to component when it's mounted */
/** HTML attributes to put directly to the input and body elements */
/** Adds custom footer to the dropdown body */
/** Disables moving the dropdown body, when togglers is moved. Used in filters panel, to prevent filter selection to 'jump' after adding a filter. */
/** CSS class(es) to put on input-part component. See https://github.com/JedWatson/classnames#usage for details */
/** CSS class(es) to put on body-part component. See https://github.com/JedWatson/classnames#usage for details */
* Enables highlighting of the items' text with search-matching results.

props.name: entityName
comment: Name of the entity being selected. Affects wording like "Please select [entity]"

props.name: entityPluralName
comment: Plural name of the entity being selected. Affects wording like "X [entities] selected"

props.name: dataSource
comment: Provides items to the Picker

props.name: getName
comment: Gets entity display name. Default it item.name.

props.name: renderRow
comment: Allow to customize how each selectable row is rendered. Can be used to add subtitles, avatars, etc.

comment: Gets options for each row. Allow to make rows non-selectable, as well as many other tweaks.

comment: Overrides the default 'no records found' banner.
The 'search' callback parameter allows to distinguish cases when there's no records at all, and when current search doesn't find anything.

typeValue.raw: undefined | (props: { search: string; onClose: () => void; }) => React.ReactNode

props.name: emptyValue
comment: Defines which value is to set on clear. E.g. you can put an empty array instead of null for empty multi-select Pickers

props.name: sortBy
comment: Defines how items should be sorted. By default, items are shown in order they are provided to the DataSource

props.name: filter
comment: Additional filter to apply to the DataSource. Can be used to limit selection somehow, w/o re-building the DataSource. E.g. in the linked pickers scenario.

props.name: sorting
comment: Defines sorting to pass to the DataSource

props.name: cascadeSelection
comment: Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
- false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
- true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
- 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.

props.name: isFoldedByDefault
comment: You can return true for all, or some items to fold them.

props.name: getSearchFields
comment: Given an item, should return an array of string fields to search on. By default, the search is performed on item.name field.

typeValue.raw: undefined | null | string | number | false | true | ClassDictionary | ClassArray

props.name: inputMode
comment: Hints at the type of data that might be entered by the user while editing the element or its contents
@see https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interaction.html#input-modalities:-the-inputmode-attribute

props.name: is
comment: Specify that a standard HTML element should behave like a defined custom built-in element
@see https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#attr-is

props.name: 'aria-activedescendant'
comment: Identifies the currently active element when DOM focus is on a composite widget, textbox, group, or application.

props.name: 'aria-atomic'
comment: Indicates whether assistive technologies will present all, or only parts of, the changed region based on the change notifications defined by the aria-relevant attribute.

props.name: 'aria-autocomplete'
comment: Indicates whether inputting text could trigger display of one or more predictions of the user's intended value for an input and specifies how predictions would be
presented if they are made.

props.name: 'aria-busy'
comment: Indicates an element is being modified and that assistive technologies MAY want to wait until the modifications are complete before exposing them to the user.

props.name: 'aria-checked'
comment: Indicates the current "checked" state of checkboxes, radio buttons, and other widgets.
@see aria-pressed @see aria-selected.

props.name: 'aria-colcount'
comment: Defines the total number of columns in a table, grid, or treegrid.
@see aria-colindex.

props.name: 'aria-colindex'
comment: Defines an element's column index or position with respect to the total number of columns within a table, grid, or treegrid.
@see aria-colcount @see aria-colspan.

props.name: 'aria-colspan'
comment: Defines the number of columns spanned by a cell or gridcell within a table, grid, or treegrid.
@see aria-colindex @see aria-rowspan.

props.name: 'aria-level'

props.name: 'aria-live'

props.name: 'aria-modal'

props.name: 'aria-multiline'

props.name: 'aria-multiselectable'

props.name: 'aria-orientation'

props.name: 'aria-owns'

props.name: entityName
comment: Name of the entity being selected. Affects wording like "Please select [entity]"

comment: Plural name of the entity being selected. Affects wording like "X [entities] selected"

props.name: dataSource
comment: Provides items to the Picker

props.name: getName
comment: Gets entity display name. Default it item.name.

props.name: renderRow
comment: Allow to customize how each selectable row is rendered. Can be used to add subtitles, avatars, etc.

comment: Gets options for each row. Allow to make rows non-selectable, as well as many other tweaks.

typeValue.raw: undefined | (item: TItem, index: number) => DataRowOptions<TItem, TId>

props.name: renderNotFound
comment: Overrides the default 'no records found' banner.
The 'search' callback parameter allows to distinguish cases when there's no records at all, and when current search doesn't find anything.

typeValue.raw: undefined | (props: { search: string; onClose: () => void; }) => React.ReactNode

props.name: emptyValue
comment: Defines which value is to set on clear. E.g. you can put an empty array instead of null for empty multi-select Pickers

props.name: sortBy
comment: Defines how items should be sorted. By default, items are shown in order they are provided to the DataSource

props.name: filter
comment: Additional filter to apply to the DataSource. Can be used to limit selection somehow, w/o re-building the DataSource. E.g. in the linked pickers scenario.

props.name: sorting
comment: Defines sorting to pass to the DataSource

props.name: cascadeSelection
comment: Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
- false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
- true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
- 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.

props.name: isFoldedByDefault
comment: You can return true for all, or some items to fold them.

props.name: getSearchFields
comment: Given an item, should return an array of string fields to search on. By default, the search is performed on item.name field.

props.name: valueType
comment: Defines what to use in value/onValueChange: 'id' - item id (TId). 'entity' - the item itself (TItem)

props.name: value
comment: The current value of component

props.name: onValueChange
comment: Called when value needs to be changed (usually due to user interaction)

props.name: isInvalid
comment: True if component contains invalid input

props.name: validationMessage
comment: Message describing why the value is invalid

props.name: validationProps
comment: If T is a complex value (object or array), this property contains validation states of inner items

props.name: isDisabled
comment: Disable editing, and visually de-emphasize value of the component

props.name: isReadonly
comment: Disable editing. Unlike isDisabled, keep component's value readable.

props.name: isRequired
comment: Marks that component's value is required

props.name: getValueChangeAnalyticsEvent
comment: Given a value, returns an analytics event to send when component is edited.
See [AnalyticsContext](@link https://uui.epam.com/documents?id=analyticsContext&mode=doc&skin=UUI4_promo&category=contexts).

props.name: onFocus
comment: Called when component gets input focus

props.name: onBlur
comment: Called when component looses input focus

props.name: placeholder
comment: Placeholder to display when empty

props.name: icon
comment: Icon can be an React element (usually an SVG element)

props.name: iconPosition
comment: Position of the icon (left of right)

props.name: onIconClick
comment: Click handler for the icon

props.name: editMode
comment: dropdown (default) - show selection in dropdown; modal - opens modal window to select items

props.name: maxItems
comment: Maximum number of tags to display in input, before collapsing to "N items selected" mode

props.name: minBodyWidth
comment: Minimum width of dropdown body

props.name: isSingleLine
comment: Prevents selected items tags to occupy multiple lines

props.name: dropdownPlacement
comment: Dropdown position relative to the input. See [Popper Docs](@link https://popper.js.org/)

props.name: renderToggler
comment: Replaces default 'toggler' - an input to which Picker attaches dropdown

props.name: searchPosition
comment: Defines where search field is:
'input' - try to place search inside the toggler (default for single-select),
'body' - put search inside the dropdown (default for multi-select)
'none' - disables search completely
Note: 'searchPosition' cannot be 'input' if 'editMode' is 'modal'

props.name: disableClear
comment: Disallow to clear Picker value (cross icon)

props.name: minCharsToSearch
comment: Minimum characters to type, before search will trigger. If input characters number is less then 'minCharsToSearch', it will disable opening dropdown body.
By default search triggers after input value is changed.
Note: defined minCharsToSearch isn't compatible with searchPosition=body.

props.name: dropdownHeight
comment: Overrides default height of the dropdown body

props.name: autoFocus
comment: Sets focus to component when it's mounted

props.name: rawProps
comment: HTML attributes to put directly to the input and body elements

props.name: renderFooter
comment: Adds custom footer to the dropdown body

props.name: fixedBodyPosition
comment: Disables moving the dropdown body, when togglers is moved. Used in filters panel, to prevent filter selection to 'jump' after adding a filter.

props.name: inputCx
comment: CSS class(es) to put on input-part component. See https://github.com/JedWatson/classnames#usage for details

props.name: bodyCx
comment: CSS class(es) to put on body-part component. See https://github.com/JedWatson/classnames#usage for details

props.name: rowKey
comment: Key to be used as component's key when rendering. Usually, it's stringified ID

props.name: index
comment: Index of the row, from the top of the list. This doesn't account any hierarchy.

props.name: parentId
comment: ID of the parent TItem

props.name: path
comment: Hierarchical path from the root node to the item (excluding the item itself)

props.name: depth
comment: Depth of the row in tree, 0 for the top-level

props.name: indent
comment: Indent of the item, to show hierarchy.
Unlike depth, it contains additional logic, to not add unnecessary indents:
if all children of node has no children, all nodes would get the same indent as parent.

props.name: isLoading
comment: True if row is in loading state. 'value' is empty in this case

props.name: isFoldable
comment: True if row be folded or unfolded (usually because it contains children)

props.name: isFolded
comment: True if row is currently folded

props.name: isChecked
comment: True if row is checked with checkbox

props.name: isCheckable
comment: True if row has checkbox and can be checkable

props.name: isChildrenChecked
comment: True if some of row's children are checked.
Used to show 'indefinite' checkbox state, to show user that something inside is checked

props.name: isSelected
comment: True if row is selected (in single-select mode, or in case when interface use both single row selection and checkboxes)

props.name: isChildrenSelected
comment: True if any of row's children is selected.

props.name: isFocused
comment: True if row is focused. Focus can be changed via keyboard arrow keys, or by hovering mouse on top of the row

props.name: isLastChild
comment: True if row is the last child of his parent

props.name: onFold
comment: Handles row folding change.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onCheck
comment: Handles row checkbox change.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onSelect
comment: Handles row selection.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onFocus
comment: Handles row focusing.

comment: Pass true to return focus into initial position on unmount.

comment: Pass true to lock focus within DropdownContainer.

print: interface PickerItemProps<TItem, TId> extends DataRowProps<TItem, TId>, SizeMod {
* Enables highlighting of the items' text with search-matching results.

props.name: highlightSearchMatches
comment: Enables highlighting of the items' text with search-matching results.
@default true

props.name: cx
comment: CSS class(es) to put on component's root. See {@link https://github.com/JedWatson/classnames#usage} for details

typeValue.raw: undefined | null | string | number | false | true | ClassDictionary | ClassArray

props.name: onClick
comment: Called when component is clicked

typeValue.raw: undefined | ((e?: any) => void) & ((rowProps: DataRowProps<TItem, TId>) => void)
undefined | null | string | number | false | true | React.ReactElement<any, string | React.JSXElementConstructor<any>> | React.ReactFragment | React.ReactPortal

props.name: rawProps
comment: Any HTML attributes (native or 'data-') to put on the underlying component

props.name: alignItems
comment: Flexbox align-items property [Flexbox Guide](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/)

props.name: columnGap
comment: Flexbox column gap property [Flexbox Guide](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/#aa-gap-row-gap-column-gap)

props.name: rowGap
comment: Flexbox row gap property [Flexbox Guide](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/#aa-gap-row-gap-column-gap)

props.name: checkbox
comment: If row needs a checkbox, this field should be specified and it props can be configured here

props.name: isSelectable
comment: True if row is selectable (for whole-row single-selection, multi-selection via checkbox are configured with the checkbox prop)

props.name: dnd
comment: Configures row drag-n-drop options - if it can be dragged, can rows can be dropped into it, etc.

props.name: link
comment: Can be specified to make row act as a link (plain or SPA)

props.name: isDisabled
comment: Disable editing, and visually de-emphasize value of the component

props.name: value
comment: The current value of component

props.name: onValueChange
comment: Called when value needs to be changed (usually due to user interaction)

props.name: isInvalid
comment: True if component contains invalid input

props.name: validationMessage
comment: Message describing why the value is invalid

props.name: validationProps
comment: If T is a complex value (object or array), this property contains validation states of inner items

props.name: isReadonly
comment: Disable editing. Unlike isDisabled, keep component's value readable.

props.name: isRequired
comment: Marks that component's value is required

props.name: id
comment: ID of the TItem rows displays

props.name: rowKey
comment: Key to be used as component's key when rendering. Usually, it's stringified ID

props.name: index
comment: Index of the row, from the top of the list. This doesn't account any hierarchy.

props.name: parentId
comment: ID of the parent TItem

props.name: path
comment: Hierarchical path from the root node to the item (excluding the item itself)

props.name: depth
comment: Depth of the row in tree, 0 for the top-level

props.name: indent
comment: Indent of the item, to show hierarchy.
Unlike depth, it contains additional logic, to not add unnecessary indents:
if all children of node has no children, all nodes would get the same indent as parent.

props.name: isLoading
comment: True if row is in loading state. 'value' is empty in this case

props.name: isFoldable
comment: True if row be folded or unfolded (usually because it contains children)

props.name: isFolded
comment: True if row is currently folded

props.name: isChecked
comment: True if row is checked with checkbox

props.name: isCheckable
comment: True if row has checkbox and can be checkable

props.name: isChildrenChecked
comment: True if some of row's children are checked.
Used to show 'indefinite' checkbox state, to show user that something inside is checked

props.name: isSelected
comment: True if row is selected (in single-select mode, or in case when interface use both single row selection and checkboxes)

props.name: isChildrenSelected
comment: True if any of row's children is selected.

props.name: isFocused
comment: True if row is focused. Focus can be changed via keyboard arrow keys, or by hovering mouse on top of the row

props.name: isLastChild
comment: True if row is the last child of his parent

props.name: onFold
comment: Handles row folding change.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onCheck
comment: Handles row checkbox change.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onSelect
comment: Handles row selection.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onFocus
comment: Handles row focusing.

props.name: onValueChange
comment: Called when value needs to be changed (usually due to user interaction)

props.name: isInvalid
comment: True if component contains invalid input

props.name: validationMessage
comment: Message describing why the value is invalid

props.name: validationProps
comment: If T is a complex value (object or array), this property contains validation states of inner items

props.name: isReadonly
comment: Disable editing. Unlike isDisabled, keep component's value readable.

props.name: isRequired
comment: Marks that component's value is required

props.name: id
comment: ID of the TItem rows displays

props.name: rowKey
comment: Key to be used as component's key when rendering. Usually, it's stringified ID

props.name: index
comment: Index of the row, from the top of the list. This doesn't account any hierarchy.

props.name: parentId
comment: ID of the parent TItem

props.name: path
comment: Hierarchical path from the root node to the item (excluding the item itself)

props.name: depth
comment: Depth of the row in tree, 0 for the top-level

props.name: indent
comment: Indent of the item, to show hierarchy.
Unlike depth, it contains additional logic, to not add unnecessary indents:
if all children of node has no children, all nodes would get the same indent as parent.

props.name: isLoading
comment: True if row is in loading state. 'value' is empty in this case

props.name: isFoldable
comment: True if row be folded or unfolded (usually because it contains children)

props.name: isFolded
comment: True if row is currently folded

props.name: isChecked
comment: True if row is checked with checkbox

props.name: isCheckable
comment: True if row has checkbox and can be checkable

props.name: isChildrenChecked
comment: True if some of row's children are checked.
Used to show 'indefinite' checkbox state, to show user that something inside is checked

props.name: isSelected
comment: True if row is selected (in single-select mode, or in case when interface use both single row selection and checkboxes)

props.name: isChildrenSelected
comment: True if any of row's children is selected.

props.name: isFocused
comment: True if row is focused. Focus can be changed via keyboard arrow keys, or by hovering mouse on top of the row

props.name: isLastChild
comment: True if row is the last child of his parent

props.name: onFold
comment: Handles row folding change.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onCheck
comment: Handles row checkbox change.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onSelect
comment: Handles row selection.
We demand to pass the row as well, to avoid creating closures for each row.

props.name: onFocus
comment: Handles row focusing.

The 'search' callback parameter allows to distinguish cases when there's no records at all, and when current search doesn't find anything.

typeValue.raw: undefined | (props: { search: string; onClose: () => void; }) => React.ReactNode

props.name: emptyValue
comment: Defines which value is to set on clear. E.g. you can put an empty array instead of null for empty multi-select Pickers

props.name: sortBy
comment: Defines how items should be sorted. By default, items are shown in order they are provided to the DataSource

props.name: filter
comment: Additional filter to apply to the DataSource. Can be used to limit selection somehow, w/o re-building the DataSource. E.g. in the linked pickers scenario.

props.name: sorting
comment: Defines sorting to pass to the DataSource

props.name: cascadeSelection
comment: Controls how the selection (checking items) of a parent node affects the selection of its all children, and vice versa.
- false: All nodes are selected independently (default).
- true or 'explicit': Selecting a parent node explicitly selects all its children. Unchecking the last parent's child unchecks its parent.
- 'implicit': Selecting a parent node means that all children are considered checked.
The user sees all these nodes as checked on the UI, but only the selected parent is visible in the PickerInput tags, and only the checked
parent is present in the Picker's value or DataSourceState.checked array. When the user unchecks the first child of such a parent,
its parents become unchecked and all children but the unchecked one become checked, making children's selection explicit. If the last
unchecked child gets checked, all children from the checked are removed, returning to the implicit state when only the parent is checked.

props.name: isFoldedByDefault
comment: You can return true for all, or some items to fold them.

props.name: getSearchFields
comment: Given an item, should return an array of string fields to search on. By default, the search is performed on item.name field.

props.name: valueType
comment: Defines what to use in value/onValueChange: 'id' - item id (TId). 'entity' - the item itself (TItem)

comment: The current value of component

props.name: onValueChange

comment: Disable editing, and visually de-emphasize value of the component

props.name: isReadonly
comment: Disable editing. Unlike isDisabled, keep component's value readable.

props.name: getValueChangeAnalyticsEvent
comment: Given a value, returns an analytics event to send when component is edited.
See [AnalyticsContext](@link https://uui.epam.com/documents?id=analyticsContext&mode=doc&skin=UUI4_promo&category=contexts).

props.name: maxDefaultItems
comment: Number of default items to show initially, when nothing is selected.
Default it 10 items

props.name: maxTotalItems
comment: Maximum total number of items to show, including selected

props.name: defaultIds
comment: Ids of items to show first.
If not specified, top props.maxDefaultItems will be shown according to the DataSource sorting settings (default is 10)

props.name: settingsKey
comment: If provided, top picks will be automatically adjusted based on last user selection, and stored as user setting under provided key

print: interface IImageElement extends TElement, PlateProps, SlateProps {

comment: Provides information about files and allows JavaScript in a web page to access their content.
[MDN Reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/File)
@internal You shouldn't need to use this type since you never see these attributes
inside your component or have to validate them.
`Element` objects are a type of node in a Slate document that contain other
element nodes or text nodes. They can be either "blocks" or "inlines"
depending on the Slate editor's configuration.
